content:
Investigation case number: AA67325. This Suspicious Activity Report is being filed to summarize structured cash deposits and subsequent international wire transfer activity conducted by John Doe, personal checking account #12345678910. John Doe has maintained this account since April 2000. At account opening and during periodic reviews, Mr. Doe identified himself as a college student employed part-time at Quickie Car Wash.

A review of account activity in March 2002 revealed a pattern of structured cash deposits followed by immediate outgoing international wire transfers. Specifically, on 03/15/02, 03/17/02, and 03/18/02, cash deposits in the amounts of $9,950.00, $9,700.00, and $10,000.00 respectively were made, totaling $29,650. These deposits were conducted on near-consecutive days and were structured at or just below the $10,000 Currency Transaction Report (CTR) threshold.

Following each cash deposit, outgoing wire transfers were initiated to Aussie Bank in Sydney, Australia, to benefit Jennifer Doe, account #981012345, whose listed address is in Australia. The outgoing wires occurred on 03/16/02 ($9,900.00), 03/18/02 ($9,700.00), and 03/19/02 ($9,900.00). The wire amounts closely correspond to the deposited cash amounts and were initiated immediately after the deposits posted to the account.

The volume, frequency, and dollar amounts of the deposits and wire transfers are inconsistent with Mr. Doe’s stated occupation and expected income as a college student working part-time. Additionally, the relationship between John Doe and the wire beneficiary, Jennifer Doe, as well as the purpose of the recurring international wire activity, remains unknown. A review of historical account activity indicates that this level and pattern of activity deviates from prior transaction behavior.

Due to the structured nature of the cash deposits, the rapid movement of funds through international wire transfers, and the inconsistency with the customer’s profile, this activity appears suspicious and indicative of potential layering. Investigation is ongoing. All records related to this SAR are maintained by the bank’s Financial Intelligence Unit in Big City, Florida.

Structuring: Cash deposits of $9,950 and $9,700 just below $10,000 CTR threshold
Deposits conducted on near-consecutive business days
Pattern consistent with possible evasion of Currency Transaction Report requirements
Rapid Movement of Funds: Immediate wire transfers following cash deposits
Outgoing wires closely matching deposited amounts
Funds quickly removed from the account after placement
International Wire Activity: Repeated wire transfers to Aussie Bank, Sydney, Australia
Single recurring foreign beneficiary: Jennifer Doe
Cross-border transfers inconsistent with customer profile
Unusual / Non-Commensurate Activity: Customer is a college student with part-time employment
Deposit amounts inconsistent with stated income
Activity deviates from historical account behavior
Layering Activity: Cash placement followed by immediate international wire transfers
Foreign beneficiary relationship and purpose unclear
